statement.text: The Planck time (tₚ ≈ 5.4 × 10⁻⁴⁴ s) represents a theoretical minimum where classical time breaks down, but it is NOT currently measurable. Current best time resolution: (1) Zeptosecond timing (~10⁻²¹ s) via photoionization, (2) Attosecond pulses (~10⁻¹⁸ s) from high-harmonic generation, (3) Atomic clock precision: Δt/t ~ 10⁻¹⁸ (fractional). We're ~23 orders of magnitude from probing Planck time.
statement.formal: Theoretical limit: tₚ = √(ℏG/c⁵) ≈ 5.391 × 10⁻⁴⁴ s; Zeptosecond: ~10⁻²¹ s; Attosecond: ~10⁻¹⁸ s; Atomic clock: Δt/t ~ 10⁻¹⁸

explanation.intuition: Like Planck length, Planck time is genuinely tiny—time for light to cross a Planck length. Our best time measurements use attosecond physics (electron dynamics) and atomic clocks (frequency standards). In 2020, physicists measured zeptosecond-scale timing (10⁻²¹ s) of photoemission in molecules. We're still 10²³× away from Planck time.
explanation.key_insight: There are TWO distinct concepts: (1) Time interval resolution (how short a pulse/event we can create/measure), (2) Time precision (how accurately we can compare clocks). Attosecond science addresses #1; atomic clocks address #2. Both push toward ~10⁻¹⁸ s scales in different ways. Planck time may represent when quantum gravity effects scramble the very concept of time ordering.
explanation.technical_details: Attosecond pulses generated via high-harmonic generation (HHG) in noble gases driven by intense femtosecond lasers. 2020 experiment timed photoelectron emission to 247 zeptoseconds. Optical atomic clocks achieve 10⁻¹⁸ fractional uncertainty—comparing two clocks over 1 second detects ~attosecond differences. Nuclear clocks (¹⁹²Th) may reach 10⁻¹⁹.

comparison_with_planck.interpretation: Like ℓₚ, tₚ is genuinely the smallest expected time scale. We're 23 orders of magnitude from probing it.

learning_objectives: Understand Planck time as possible fundamental minimum
Know that zeptosecond timing has been achieved
Distinguish time interval measurement from clock precision
common_misconceptions: Planck time IS likely a true minimum (like Planck length)
We are 23 orders of magnitude from probing Planck time
Attosecond ≠ shortest time—zeptoseconds have been measured
